principles.name: Segmentation
principles.description: Divide an object into independent parts.
examples: Modular furniture that can be rearranged

principles.name: Taking out
principles.description: Extract the disturbing part or property from an object.

principles.name: Local quality
principles.description: Change an object's structure from uniform to non-uniform.
examples: Golf club with different materials for the shaft and head
Sandpaper with varying grit sizes in different areas

principles.name: Asymmetry
principles.description: Change the shape of an object from symmetrical to asymmetrical.

principles.name: Merging
principles.description: Bring closer together identical or similar objects.
examples: Smartphone combining phone, camera, and computer

principles.name: Universality
principles.description: Make an object perform multiple functions, eliminating the need for other objects.
examples: Smartphone that serves as phone, camera, and computer

principles.name: Nesting
principles.description: Place one object inside another, which is placed inside a third, and so on.

principles.name: Anti-weight
principles.description: To compensate for the weight of an object, merge it with other objects that provide lift.
examples: Helium balloons to support holiday decorations
Aircraft wing design to create lift

principles.name: Preliminary anti-action
principles.description: If an action will have both harmful and useful effects, perform a counter-action in advance.
examples: Pre-heating an engine in cold weather

principles.name: Preliminary action
principles.description: Perform the required change of an object in advance, either fully or partially.

principles.name: Beforehand cushioning
principles.description: Prepare emergency means beforehand to compensate for the relatively low reliability of an object.

principles.name: Equipotentiality
principles.description: Change the condition of work so that an object doesn't need to be raised or lowered.
examples: Mid-ship fuel tanks to balance the ship

principles.name: The other way around
principles.description: Invert the action used to solve the problem. Make movable parts fixed, and fixed parts movable.
examples: Moving sidewalk with people standing still
Fixed hammer with moving nail for industrial hammering

principles.name: Spheroidality
principles.description: Replace linear parts with curved ones, flat surfaces with spherical ones, and cube shapes with ball shapes.
examples: Dome-shaped buildings for better wind resistance

principles.name: Dynamics
principles.description: Allow the characteristics of an object to change to be optimal for each stage of an operation.
examples: Power steering that changes resistance with speed

principles.name: Partial or excessive actions
principles.description: If 100% of an objective is hard to achieve, use 'slightly less' or 'slightly more' to simplify the problem.
examples: Overspray when painting to ensure complete coverage
Ordering extra building materials to account for waste
Fill a measuring cup slightly above the line to account for spillage

principles.name: Another dimension
principles.description: Move into an additional dimension; use a multi-story arrangement instead of a single-story one.
examples: Bookcase instead of a row of books

principles.name: Mechanical vibration
principles.description: Cause an object to oscillate or vibrate; increase its frequency.

principles.name: Periodic action
principles.description: Replace continuous action with periodic or pulsating actions.

principles.name: Continuity of useful action
principles.description: Carry on work continuously; make all parts of an object work at full load, all the time.

principles.name: Skipping
principles.description: Conduct a process, or certain stages, at high speed to avoid harmful effects.
examples: High-speed surgical procedures to reduce patient trauma

principles.name: Blessing in disguise
principles.description: Turn harmful factors into benefits; amplify a harmful factor to the point where it is no longer harmful.
examples: Judo using an attacker's strength against them
Vaccine using weakened pathogen to build immunity

principles.name: Feedback
principles.description: Introduce feedback to improve a process or action.
examples: Automatic gain control in audio systems
Blood glucose monitors for diabetes management

principles.name: Intermediary
principles.description: Use an intermediary carrier article or intermediary process.
examples: Car jack to lift a car
Agent or broker in business transactions

principles.name: Self-service
principles.description: Make an object serve itself by performing auxiliary functions.

principles.name: Copying
principles.description: Use a simple and inexpensive copy instead of an object that is complex, expensive, or fragile.
examples: Crash test dummy instead of human
Digital document copies instead of original

principles.name: Cheap short-living objects
principles.description: Replace an expensive object with multiple cheap ones, compromising certain qualities.

principles.name: Mechanics substitution
principles.description: Replace a mechanical means with sensory (optical, acoustic, taste or smell) means.
examples: Using light or sound signals instead of physical barriers

principles.name: Pneumatics and hydraulics
principles.description: Use gas and liquid parts of an object instead of solid parts.

principles.name: Flexible shells and thin films
principles.description: Use flexible shells and thin films instead of three dimensional structures.

principles.name: Porous materials
principles.description: Make an object porous or add porous elements.
examples: Foam core doors for better insulation

principles.name: Color changes
principles.description: Change the color of an object or its external environment.

principles.name: Homogeneity
principles.description: Make objects interact with a given object of the same material.

principles.name: Discarding and recovering
principles.description: Make portions of an object that have fulfilled their functions disappear or modify them directly during operation.
examples: Ice cube tray with removable dividers

principles.name: Parameter changes
principles.description: Change an object's physical state, concentration, consistency, temperature, or other parameters.
examples: Freeze water to create ice road
Evaporate water to create steam power
Heat treat metal to change properties

principles.name: Phase transitions
principles.description: Use phenomena occurring during phase transitions.
examples: Heat pipes using evaporation and condensation

principles.name: Thermal expansion
principles.description: Use thermal expansion or contraction of materials.

principles.name: Strong oxidants
principles.description: Replace common air with enriched air or pure oxygen; expose to air or oxygen.

principles.name: Inert atmosphere
principles.description: Replace a normal environment with an inert one.

principles.name: Composite materials
principles.description: Change from uniform to composite materials.

principles.name: Adjustment
principles.description: Adjust parameters to achieve optimal performance under varying conditions.

principles.name: Dynamic Reconfiguration
principles.description: Enable system components to rearrange themselves as needed.

principles.name: Energy Redistribution
principles.description: Reallocate energy within a system to optimize performance.

principles.name: Multi-state Operation
principles.description: Design a system to function effectively in multiple operational states.
examples: Hybrid vehicles with multiple drive modes

principles.name: Non-linear Interactions
principles.description: Utilize non-linear relationships between system components.

principles.name: Self-diagnosis
principles.description: Enable a system to detect and identify its own faults or suboptimal states.

principles.name: Information Compression
principles.description: Reduce the amount of data needed while preserving essential information.

principles.name: Resource Recycling
principles.description: Reuse waste products or energy within the system.

principles.name: Scalability
principles.description: Design systems that can be effectively scaled up or down without redesign.

principles.name: Boundary Condition Optimization
principles.description: Focus on optimizing the interfaces between system components.

principles.name: Interoperability
principles.description: Enable seamless interaction between different systems and components.

principles.name: Emotion Recognition
principles.description: Incorporate the ability to detect and respond to human emotional states.

principles.name: Stochastic Optimization
principles.description: Use randomness in a controlled way to find better solutions.

principles.name: Energy Field Manipulation
principles.description: Control and direct energy fields to achieve desired effects.

principles.name: Wave Control
principles.description: Manipulate wave properties such as phase, frequency, and amplitude.

principles.name: Time Management
principles.description: Optimize the temporal aspects of system operation.

principles.name: Flexibility
principles.description: Design systems that can adapt to changing requirements and conditions.

principles.name: Molecular Level Control
principles.description: Manipulate matter at the molecular or atomic level.

principles.name: Feedback Loop Enhancement
principles.description: Improve the quality, speed, or effectiveness of feedback mechanisms.

principles.name: Variable Connectivity
principles.description: Allow dynamic changes in how system components connect to each other.
